page.title: 06MASTER THATCHER
page.content: There are several thatched cottages in Clipston. Mr Davis learned to thatch in 1950, at Wellingborough. He stayed there 4 years. To become a Master Thatcher his work was checked by officials over a period of 12 months. At present he is working on Mrs Bevis White's house in Clipston. It will take 12 months to finish. The roof needs 3200 bundles. There are 55 bundles to a fathom, which is 6ft. in diameter. The water reed grows in Norfolk, and can grow up to 8ft. tall. It goes yellow in September and is cut between March and December. Hazel sticks are used because they do not break easily. Leggets drive the reed upwards. Needles hold the thatch in place, long knives cut the sedge. The advantage of thatch is that it keeps a house warmer than a tiled roof.
